conclusion: Determine if the rate distribution curve changes from state D to state A.
Process A→B is an isothermal expansion.
Temperature is constant during A→B, so the rate distribution curve remains the same.
Process B→C is an adiabatic expansion.
Temperature decreases during B→C, shifting the rate distribution curve.
Process C→D is an isothermal compression.
Temperature is constant during C→D, so the rate distribution curve remains unchanged.
Process D→A is an adiabatic compression.
Temperature increases during D→A, shifting the rate distribution curve.
State D and state A have different temperatures, so their rate distribution curves differ.
Rate distribution curve at state A is broader and has a higher peak than at state D.
The rate distribution curve of the gas molecule changes from state D to state A.
